climbs.name: The Underdiddled
climbs.fa: Rick Thompson, Mike Artz, Rob Turan 1987

content.description: Start in the flake system and climb up to the roof.  Move right, clip the bolt and continue to the top.  The crux is right at the bolt, but the top can be a bit heady.  The finish is a bit dirty.
content.protection: 1 bolt, standard New River rack.  A very small micronut can be placed on the dirty finish.
content.location: Start in the middle of the face under a roof just to the left of Kidspeak.

content.description:
Climb to the top of the 4 inch crack, plug some gear, and find your smeary slab feet. Aim for the crack up and left. Jugs galore and top out through sketchy terrain and lots of briars.

This thing takes great gear and if it had anchors would see more traffic. Way more fun than it looks.
content.location: Start on 4 inch crack in detached slab.

content.description:
One of my favorites at Ambassador! Crimpy slab climbing and technical movements the whole way. If you enjoy slabs, this climb is worth the trip to this small and obscure area.

This climb is essentially a sport route and is possible to be climbed on just the bolts. However it's less heady if you take some gear mostly for the start and potentially a few other places.
content.protection: A single rack should suffice with 3 bolts and anchors.
content.location: On a slabby wall near the end of the area. After Liddlebiddanuthin' and before Consenting Clips.

climbs.name: Nookie Monster
climbs.fa: Glenn Thomas, Mark Van Cura, Rick Thompson, Carl Samples, Scott Garso 1987

content.description: Climb the hand crack to the top.
content.location: The first obvious hand crack you find as you approach the cliff from the knotted rope descent on the right side of the cliff.

content.description: Climb up the arete with very thin moves passing some very shallow horizontals to a good stance(crux).  Continue up and join the upper portion of Lunar Tunes for the finish.
content.protection: 1 pin, 1 bolt.  Some micro gear and stuff up to a #2 camalot.
content.location: Start on the arete, just past Lunar Tunes and The Underdiddled.

content.description: Climb the large flake system to the base of the roof and then traverse towards the arete and where the roof tapers out. Establishing yourself on the arete above is the crux. Follow the arete to a two-bolt anchor. If you manage the rope drag well, it's a worthwhile route if you find yourself in the area.
content.protection: Standard NRG rack. A #4 might be nice, but is certainly not needed. Two-bolt anchor that can be accessed easily from the top.

climbs.name: Kidspeak
climbs.fa: Eric Anderson, Doug Chapman, Paul Goesling 1983

content.description: Climb the finger crack in a short dihedral.  Fairly sustained for the 30 Ft. of climbing.
content.location: The next obvious crack climb after passing Nookie Monster.

content.description:
Start on a small block left of the first bolt and climb up and right following crimps and pockets to the first bolt. Angle left to the second bolt and then immediately back right towards the anchors.

This route meanders a bit, but with the general directions given above it's not too hard to find the path of least resistance. Climbing is mostly vertical with some slightly steep sections. Be ready for bigger moves on crimps and pockets.
content.protection: A light rack up to BD .5, 2 bolts and anchors. Some small gear (Purple C3ish) might help protect before the first bolt.
content.location: The first line just around the corner from the Bolting Blowfish.

content.description: Great route that starts out as a fist and wide hand crack for a little more than the first half and then changes up to some face climbing to the top.
content.protection: Standard rack up to fist size (BD #4), 2 bolts and anchors.
content.location: Obvious wide crack past New-veau Reach and before Fear of Dreads.

climbs.name: The Bolting Blowfish
climbs.fa: Eddie Begoon, Mike Artz, Rick Thompson 1987

content.description: A perfect balancy face climb, with your mandatory long NRG moves and a thought-provoking crux. This may just be the first sport route in the gorge, a wonderful climb deserving of this coveted title! Originally this route had two bolts and two pins, now it sports 3 bolts and no pins. A very light rack will suffice for this route.
content.location: The climb is on the detachment just downstream from the sport lines (short & dirty) and Clumsy Club Crack. Look for the three bolts with the bolt anchor atop.

climbs.name: Chasing Rainbows
climbs.fa: Eddie Begoon, Rick Thompson, Bill Moore, Bob Rentka 1987

content.description: This route has really cool moves!  Thin and balancy.  Climb the face and flake with some traversing to reach the top.
content.protection: Thin gear, tri cams may be helpful.
content.location: Locate the second upstream facing white face just downsteam from New-veau Reach and Lunar Times. Start near a large boulder.
